history.content:
It depends what you want to do in industry and which class you think you have a better shot of getting into in the future. 

160 is good if you want to do front-end work, or want an understanding of mobile or web frameworks, have an interest in human computer interaction, or just want to learn how to make your programs more useable for an end user. This class seems to be particularly applicable if you wish to become a front-end developer at an company.

C100 is good if you’re interested in either pursuing the data science major/minor (since it is a requirement) or want to learn about data visualization and statistical analysis techniques. I reckon this class is essential if you're looking to go into the data science field in industry.

C100 is considered to be one of the lighter upper divs, comparable to CS 61A. 160 tends to vary a lot in workload by professor.

C100 is considered to be one of the lighter upper divs, comparable to CS 61A. 160 tends to vary a lot in workload by professor.

I think I already answered your follow up question on one of the earlier posts. That being said, I think it depends what you want to do in industry and which class you think you have a better shot of getting into in the future. 

160 is good if you want to do front-end work, or want an understanding of mobile or web frameworks, have an interest in human computer interaction, or just want to learn how to make your programs more useable for an end user. This class seems to be applicable if you wish to become a front-end developer at an company.

C100 is good if you’re interested in either pursuing the data science major/minor (since it is a requirement) or want to learn about data visualization and statistical analysis techniques. I reckon this class is essential if you're looking to go into the data science field in industry.

C100 is considered to be one of the lighter upper divs, comparable to CS 61A. 160 tends to vary a lot in workload by professor.

I think I already answered your follow up question on one of the earlier posts. That being said, I think it depends what you want to do in industry and which class you think you have a better shot of getting into in the future. 

160 is good if you want to do front-end work, or want an understanding of mobile or web frameworks, have an interest in human computer interaction, or just want to learn how to make your programs more useable for an end user. 

C100 is good if you’re interested in big data, statistical analysis, analytics, and the wonderful world of data. 

I am currently in C100, so can’t speak to the workload, but it seems to be one of the lighter upper divs. 160 tends to vary a lot in workload by Professor.

Currently I plan to take EE16A and 61C and I'm debating which one to keep between CS 160 and CS C100. Which schedule would be more doable or useful for industry? For reference, I have only taken 61A, 61B, and 70.
history.subject: CS 160 or CS C100?
